posts.post_content:
This card would've been terrible even by Homelands standards. It's actually kind of nostalgic to see awful underpowered creatures like this. Makes me long for my first games of Magic, where we'd just take the huge box of junk cards someone's older brother gave us, each take all the cards of a single color, and proceed to hammer at each other with [Gray Ogre](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gray Ogre) and [Silver Erne](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Silver Erne).  
  
One difference I've noticed aside from the power level is that for a long time there seemed to be a pretty clear formula for how much total power/toughness you get for your mana: 2 for 1, 4 for 2, 5 for 3, 6-7 for 4, 8-9 for 5, 10-11 for 6. Special abilities like flying, first strike, or trample were worth 1 power or toughness point. If you wanted to print a creature that was stronger than its mana cost would allow, you gave it drawbacks, which made players think hard about how to minimize those drawbacks or even turn them into advantages. Now, there doesn't seem to be any c... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

This card would've been terrible even by Homelands standards. It's actually kind of nostalgic to see awful underpowered creatures like this. Makes me long for my first games of Magic, where we'd just take the huge box of junk cards someone's older brother gave us, each take all the cards of a single color, and proceed to hammer at each other with Gray Ogre and Silver Erne.

One difference I've noticed aside from the power level is that for a long time there seemed to be a pretty clear formula for how much total power/toughness you get for your mana: 2 for 1, 4 for 2, 5 for 3, 6-7 for 4, 8-9 for 5, 10-11 for 6. Special abilities like flying, first strike, or trample were worth 1 power or toughness point. If you wanted to print a creature that was stronger than its mana cost would allow, you gave it drawbacks, which made players think hard about how to minimize those drawbacks or even turn them into advantages. Now, there doesn't seem to be any c... (see all)

Posted By: Mumba (12/15/2009 8:00:31 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: Will you people quit bitching? Zendikar was overpowered by ANY standard, and if it weren't for the possibility of things like this taking up common slots, every pack would have sold out in a week, just like the Innistrad incident. True, it is a mistake, and Wizards did think it was funny, but you know what? It was. Just like [Chimney Imp](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Chimney Imp), a card this awful in a set this amazing just highlights the good and bad parts of the set, and makes it easier for new players to know what to draft. 0.5/5, sure, hell 5x10^-42/5, but it's funny, and kind of necessary. I won't thank you, Mindless Null, but I will shake your hand and not be embarrassed. Goodbye, and don't ever, EVER come back.
posts.html:
